author: By Robert F. Worth
title: The Appalling Treatment of a Prisoner at Guantánamo
description: “The Forever Prisoner,” by Cathy Scott-Clark and Adrian Levy, tells the story of a man who has been held captive by the C.I.A. for 20 years.
content: THE FOREVER PRISONERThe Full and Searing Account of the C.I.A.’s Most Controversial Covert ProgramBy Cathy Scott-Clark and Adrian Levy
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Lisa Friedman
title: Gas Prices Force Biden Into an Unlikely Embrace of Fossil Fuels
description: President Biden has had to walk a careful tightrope on energy and climate change in the weeks since U.S. sanctions on Russian oil and gas sent energy prices soaring.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden came into office promising to tackle the planet’s climate crisis. But rising gas prices, driven in part by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, have pushed the environmental-minded president to do something unlikely: embrace oil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Macbeth’ restarted Broadway performances on Tuesday as four shows reeling from the virus seek to resume.
description: The shows are facing challenges as new coronavirus cases rise in New York City, though the average number of new cases remains far lower than during the winter Omicron peak.
content: A new production of “Macbeth” starring Daniel Craig and Ruth Negga resumed performances on Tuesday night, 11 days after it shut down because of positive coronavirus tests among company members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Swanson
title: Passing the Last Puzzle Piece to the Next Generation
description: Amid great loss, a tradition is carried on.
content: I barely remember the hours between my father’s death and my departure. There was chaos. Frantic planning. Deep, unimaginable grief. I packed as quickly as I could and kissed my children goodbye. I left before sunrise to drive 900 miles, straight to my childhood home — where my parents lived together for more than 50 years — so I could hug my mother and cry in her arms. There were devastating phone calls to make and things to sort. She needed help packing her own bags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dominique Moïsi
title: France’s Voters Are Choosing Between Fear and Anger
description: Marine Le Pen and Emmanuel Macron are courting voters with emotion.
content: PARIS — The future of democracy in Europe is being decided simultaneously on the battlefields of Ukraine and in the ballot boxes of France.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Diana Nguyen, Luke Vander Ploeg, John Ketchum, M.J. Davis Lin, Brad Fisher, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: Biden’s Climate Shift
description: The war in Ukraine has led the president to retreat on his ambitious climate policies.
content: On the campaign trail and when he first came to office, President Biden had ambitious plans to deal with climate change, including promises to reduce fossil fuel production.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Putin’s defiance
description: The Russian president insists that Russia’s war goals will be achieved.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: In a First, Google Goes After Puppy Fraud in Court
description: The company’s first consumer protection lawsuit, filed Monday,  claims a Cameroon man tricked would-be buyers using Gmail and other services.
content: In a first for the tech giant, Google filed a consumer protection lawsuit to shield the vulnerable and unsuspecting from what it called a “nefarious” scheme: the sale of adorable, but imaginary, puppies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: Sri Lanka stops debt payments as economic crisis deepens.
description: The government seeks to ease financial pressure as foreign reserves plummet and prices for essential goods soar.
content: Sri Lanka suspended payments on its international debt Tuesday, effectively putting the small island nation in default as it plunges deeper into an economic crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Inflation Hits Fastest Pace Since 1981, at 8.5% Through March
description: Gasoline weighed heavily in the increases, while prices moderated in several categories. Some economists say the overall rate may have peaked.
content: Inflation hit 8.5 percent in the United States last month, the fastest 12-month pace since 1981, as a surge in gasoline prices tied to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine added to sharp increases coming from the collision of strong demand and stubborn pandemic-related supply shortages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Healy and Adrian J. Rivera
title: These 8 Conservative Men Are Making No Apologies
description: A group of conservative men spoke with Times Opinion about what it’s like to be a man in America today, touching on cancel culture, race and gender.
content: There was no talk of a stolen election, no conspiracy theories about voter fraud or rants about President Biden’s legitimacy. Yet listening to our 90-minute focus group with eight conservative men, you couldn’t help but worry for our democracy a bit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez and Lisette  Poole
title: This Beach in Mexico Is an L.G.B.T.Q. Haven. But Can It Last?
description: The town of Zipolite has become an oasis for the queer community. But as its popularity has surged, some worry that the town’s spirit is beginning to vanish.
content: ZIPOLITE, Mexico — When the sun starts to slip toward the ocean in this idyllic beach town on Mexico’s Pacific Coast, a quiet migration begins. Groups of people, most of them gay men, many of them naked, amble down the beach toward a soaring rocky outcrop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China Sets Aside Push to Spread Wealth in Pivotal Year for Xi
description: Xi Jinping’s rhetoric about redistributing wealth was aimed partly at drumming up public support. But it unnerved entrepreneurs and posed a drag on growth.
content: BEIJING — For much of last year, China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, waged a fierce campaign to rein in private capital and narrow social inequalities. Regulators cracked down on tech giants and wealthy celebrities. Beijing demanded that tycoons give back to society. And the Communist Party promised that a new era of “common prosperity” was on the horizon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Commuters are frightened by subway attack but say, ‘You can’t live in fear.’
description: Some passengers learned of the shooting through station announcements, messages from friends and family, and news alerts, while others did not know about it at all.
content: It was about 11:40 a.m. when a few cellphones on a Brooklyn-bound F train wailed with an emergency alert on Tuesday morning, warning New Yorkers to steer clear of the area where a man had shot 10 people in the subway in the Sunset Park neighborhood hours earlier. Two men passed the phone to each other, wondering how to get to their stop. Elsewhere on the sparsely filled car, people read books, listened to music, watched videos or texted on their phones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Tuesday’s shooting is reminiscent of a string of other attacks in recent years.
description: Mass shootings in New York — attacks in which multiple people are shot — occur with some regularity. Just last week, three teenagers were shot in the crossfire outside a Bronx high school; one, a 16-year-old girl, died.
content: Mass shootings in New York — attacks in which multiple people are shot — occur with some regularity. Just last week, three teenagers were shot in the crossfire outside a Bronx high school; one, a 16-year-old girl, died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Hughes
title: Viola Davis, Inside Out
description: How she drew on a life of private hardship to become one of the greatest actors of her generation.
content: For a month, Viola Davis had been stuck. In the spring of 2020, in the late nights of lockdown, she set out to write her memoir. She had her routine: Get out of bed in the middle of the night, make herself a cup of tea, start writing in her movie room, fall asleep in one of its leather recliners, wake up, write some more, nod off again. But for weeks, she couldn’t figure out exactly where to begin. Should she start with her life as a celebrity, or the beauty contest she lost when she was a child, or the fact that people always wanted to hug her when they ran into her in public? Nothing worked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Is Driving High as Dangerous as Driving Drunk?
description: There’s limited data on how marijuana impacts driving performance, but experts urge caution before getting behind the wheel.
content: Q: I know all about the dangers of driving while drunk. But is driving while high on marijuana as dangerous?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Macron and Le Pen Trade Jabs and Lean Left as French Race Heats Up
description: President Emmanuel Macron and Marine Le Pen, the far-right candidate, are in close contention as the April 24 presidential runoff election nears.
content: PARIS — France’s presidential election entered a new, intense phase on Tuesday as President Emmanuel Macron and Marine Le Pen, the far-right candidate trying to unseat him, traded barbs from afar and rubbed shoulders with voters in hopes of widening their appeal, especially on the left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Inflation Is About to Come Down — but Don’t Get Too Excited
description: The bullwhip is flicking back.
content: The inflation report for March came in hot, as expected: Consumer prices are up 8.5 percent over the past year. But more than two years into the pandemic, we’re still living on Covid time, where things can change very fast — so fast that official data, even about the recent past, can give a misleading picture of what’s happening now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Alaska Man Who Threatened to Kill U.S. Senators Gets Nearly 3 Years in Prison
description: Prosecutors said that Jay Allen Johnson left 17 threatening and expletive-laden voicemails over five months for Senators Lisa Murkowski and Dan Sullivan, both of Alaska.
content: An Alaska man who pleaded guilty to threatening to murder two U.S. senators has been sentenced to 32 months in prison and a $5,000 fine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Fondren
title: Gay Couple Was Denied I.V.F. Benefits. They Say That’s Discriminatory.
description: A former lawyer for New York City and his husband have filed a complaint against the city saying they were denied insurance coverage because of a definition of infertility that excludes gay men.
content: A same-sex married couple said in a complaint filed Tuesday that the City of New York discriminated against them in denying them in vitro fertilization coverage under the city’s insurance plan for employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: What Do We Do if Putin Uses Chemical Weapons?
description: We can’t afford to repeat our mistakes in Syria.
content: There are reports that Russia may be planning to use — or, according to unverified reports from local officials in Mariupol, might have already used — chemical weapons as part of its offensive in eastern Ukraine. The Biden administration has already set up a Tiger Team of national security officials to consider options in the event this happens; now is the time for these discussions to become more public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Covid in the Northeast
description: Cases are rising there, but it’s uncertain if it’s the beginning of a larger surge.
content: Covid outbreaks in elite circles in Washington, D.C., and on Broadway have received a lot of media attention in recent days, but they appear to be only one part of a broader regional rise in infections: States in the Northeast are now reporting an uptick in cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joyce Maynard
title: Delia Ephron’s Memoir Could Be Called ‘Love, Loss and Love Again’
description: In “Left on Tenth,” the veteran author looks back on a series of life-altering events, including a whirlwind romance at the age of 72.
content: LEFT ON TENTHA Second Chance at LifeBy Delia Ephron
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Laurence Fishburne Cools Down With Classic Jazz and Cashmere Blankets
description: The actor is back on Broadway for a revival of David Mamet’s “American Buffalo.” He discusses his other must-haves, like a chef’s knife, trampolines and crystals.
content: “I have a working knowledge of what my gifts are,” Laurence Fishburne said. “I’ve been blessed with a wonderful voice. And I have a real innate sense of the dramatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Goldberger
title: Not Your Grandfather’s Skyscraper
description: Stefan Al’s “Supertall” is a thoughtful inquiry into the new generation of skyscrapers, which are taller and more ubiquitous than their predecessors.
content: The unrelenting construction of bigger and bigger skyscrapers in New York City is “shutting out the light of the heavens and circumscribing the air of the streets,” robbing citizens of their rights to light and air, “which, ‘in the pursuit of health, happiness and prosperity,’ they should demand,” wrote an architect named David Knickerbocker Boyd, who called the newest crop of tall towers “a menace to public health and safety and an offense which must be stopped.” Boyd’s view of the skyscraper as an urban plague makes him sound as if he were leading the charge against the forest of pencil-thin, ultra-tall towers that has sprung up lately on Billionaires’ Row in Midtown Manhattan. He might have done just that, had he not died in 1944. Boyd’s jeremiad was written 114 years ago, when anything with more than a dozen floors was considered a skyscraper, and the tallest building in the world was Ernest Flagg’s just-finished Singer Building at Broadway and Liberty Street, which rose to the then unheard-of height of 47 stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden will allow summertime sales of higher-ethanol gas.
description: The White House estimated that the move would allow Americans to save 10 cents a gallon at the approximately 2,300 stations in the country that offer the blend known as E15.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden announced on Tuesday a plan to suspend a ban on summertime sales of higher-ethanol gasoline blends, a move that White House officials said was aimed at reducing gas prices but that energy experts predicted would have only a marginal impact at the pump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: South Dakota Lawmakers Impeach Attorney General Involved in Fatal Crash
description: Attorney General Jason R. Ravnsborg will face a trial in the State Senate to determine whether he is removed from office.
content: The South Dakota House of Representatives voted on Tuesday to impeach the state’s attorney general, Jason R. Ravnsborg, who fatally struck a man with his car in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Anton Troianovski
title: Ukraine says a political ally of Putin has been detained in a ‘special operation.’
description: Viktor Medvedchuk, a wealthy Ukrainian politician seen as the Kremlin’s main agent of influence in Ukraine in recent years, had disappeared shortly after the start of the war.
content: Ukraine’s security service said on Tuesday that officers had detained Viktor Medvedchuk, a politician and oligarch seen as the Kremlin’s main agent of influence in Ukraine in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Need a Haggadah? There’s a QR Code for That.
description: Some shun phones at the Seder table. But, these days, some also welcome them.
content: Every year, the Lawrenceville School, a boarding and day school in New Jersey, has a large Passover Seder for students, family members, alumni and faculty. After doing the Seder remotely in 2020 and in a tent in 2021, they will be back inside this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Henderson
title: What It Will Mean as Europe Frees Itself From Russian Energy
description: Soaring energy prices may speed the continent’s move to a green energy future.
content: Europe has benefited from relatively cheap natural gas from Russia for decades. But for all the talk now of diversifying away from this supply, the plain reality is that it will not be easy to find alternatives. It will be a yearslong undertaking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: PFAS: The ‘Forever Chemicals’ You Couldn’t Escape if You Tried
description: Virtually indestructible, these artificial compounds are used in fast-food packaging and countless household items, but they have been found as far away as virgin forests.
content: Based on nothing more than their name, per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances certainly don’t sound like something you’d want to find in your burger wrapper. But according to a recent investigation by Consumer Reports, they’re very much there — as well as in your salad bowl, fry bag and sandwich wrap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano and Paul Mozur
title: Nokia joins Ericsson as telecom giants leave Russia.
description: The decisions by the two Nordic firms signal difficulties ahead for Russia’s ability to expand and maintain its telecommunications networks.
content: Nokia, whose telecommunications equipment plays an important role providing internet and communications in Russia, said on Tuesday that it was exiting the country because of the invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Is Another Covid Surge Coming to California?
description: Coronavirus cases in the Golden State have increased by 18 percent over the past two weeks.
content: Rising coronavirus cases in the Northeast and the proliferation of the highly transmissible BA.2 subvariant raise the inevitable question: Is another Covid surge coming to California?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Laughs Off Trump’s Shilling for Dr. Oz
description: “Come on, he’s a con man. And so is Dr. Oz,” Colbert joked of the former president.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: French Authorities Seize Oligarch’s Painting Before It Leaves for Russia
description: A work displayed in the blockbuster “Morozov Collection” exhibition will remain in France, and authorities have their eyes on another painting in the show.
content: A painting owned by a Russian oligarch that was seen by over 1.2 million people who visited a blockbuster art show in Paris will not be returning to Russia for the foreseeable future, a spokesman for France’s culture ministry said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing’s sales rebound continues, with the 737 Max leading the way.
description: The company had net sales of 145 aircraft in the first three months of the year as airlines got ready for a resurgence in travel.
content: Boeing sold 145 planes in the first three months of the year, after accounting for canceled orders, the company said on Tuesday, as airlines around the world start to lay the groundwork for a broader postpandemic rebound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: Uber and Lyft will refund customers charged with surge prices near the site of the shooting.
description: The ride-share apps said they had paused surge pricing for rides ordered near the site of the shooting.
content: Ride-share apps Uber and Lyft announced on Tuesday that they had paused surge pricing for rides ordered near the site of the shooting and would refund surge fees charged after the shooting happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: U.S. Crackdown Targets Boxing Figure Accused of Organized Crime
description: Daniel Kinahan is accused of leading an Irish organized crime group, and he has been involved with some of boxing’s biggest stars, including Tyson Fury.
content: The U.S. government announced a severe crackdown Tuesday on Daniel Kinahan, the accused head of an Irish organized crime group who has long been involved in boxing, including with one of its biggest stars, Tyson Fury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Ukraine Says It Thwarted a Sophisticated Russian Cyberattack on Its Power Grid
description: Experts say the hacking, while unsuccessful, was among the most complex cyberattacks they have seen in the war so far.
content: WASHINGTON — Ukrainian officials said on Tuesday that they had thwarted a Russian cyberattack on Ukraine’s power grid that could have knocked out power to two million people, raising fears that Moscow will increase its use of digital weapons in a country already pummeled by war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amir-Hussein Radjy
title: Shocking the Bourgeoisie With Iran’s Misunderstood Modernist
description: “Blind Owl,” by Sadeq Hedayat, is a hallucinatory short novel that upends Persian artistic traditions.
content: In April 1951, the police in Paris called on my great-grandfather, Prince Mohamed-Hussein Firouz, to identify a dead body. It was that of Sadeq Hedayat, who is today eulogized as Iran’s great literary modernist. Days before, Hedayat had sealed up the apartment on Rue Championnet where he was staying and opened up the oven’s gas valve before lying down on the kitchen floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Real Madrid Ousts Chelsea by Turning a Collapse Into a Classic
description: A curving assist by Luka Modric and an extra-time header by Karim Benzema carried Real Madrid back to the Champions League semifinals.
content: MADRID — The noise rose and swelled with every second that ticked, changing timbre and tone as it did so. It started with whistles, desperate and urgent, only to turn into something closer to a roar, formless and elemental, filled with angst and anticipation, as if the sound itself could ward off any more suffering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall, Troy Closson and Sean Piccoli
title: A Rise in Murders Upends a Sense of Progress in Brooklyn’s East Flatbush
description: The killing of a 12-year-old boy in the neighborhood captured how a spike in shootings during the pandemic is complicating recovery in less affluent neighborhoods.
content: On March’s final evening, a stolen car made its fourth pass down a quiet Brooklyn block and slowed to a stop before a row of neat brick homes. A gunman braced in the sunroof, then opened fire on three cousins having dinner in a parked car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: Margo Jefferson’s New Memoir Experiments With the Form in Startling Ways
description: Jefferson’s “Constructing a Nervous System,” a companion to her earlier “Negroland,” explores the materials used to make identity and art.
content: If Margo Jefferson had gone into another profession — cabinetmaking, let’s say — she’d be the type to draw and redraw plans for a cabinet, build and tinker with the cabinet, stand back to look at the cabinet from every angle, probe the purpose of woodworking, take a break to go examine 2,000 other cabinets, then disassemble her own product and start from scratch with alternative tools, creating an object that no longer resembled a cabinet but performed all the functions of one in startling ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum, Nicholas Fandos and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Lt. Gov. Benjamin Resigns Following Campaign Finance Indictment
description: Brian A. Benjamin, New York’s second in command to Gov. Kathy Hochul, was charged with bribery, fraud and falsification of records while a state senator.
content: Lt. Gov. Brian A. Benjamin of New York resigned on Tuesday, hours after federal prosecutors unsealed an indictment implicating him in a brazen scheme to enrich his political campaigns with illegal donations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Live Webinar: Exploring Big Ideas Through Short Documentaries
description: Join us on April 28 as Learning Network editors discuss how our weekly Film Club feature can be used across the curriculum.
content: In addition to the hundreds of articles published daily, The New York Times creates innovative visual storytelling through film and video. Times Video series — like Op-Docs, Modern Love, Diary of a Song and Conception — offer viewers an intriguing and unique perspective of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Where Do You Go to Find Cool, Strange or Fascinating Information on the Internet?
description: An Instagram account is dedicated to highlighting strange, obscure and interesting facts found on Wikipedia. Where do you go to find hidden gems on the internet?
content: Do you regularly visit Wikipedia? What kinds of things do you look up? Do you ever search for intriguing, funny or strange facts or trivia? For example, are you interested in discovering a political party dedicated to opposing the use of PowerPoint? Or learning about the world’s most unwanted song? Or maybe finding photos of a chicken — yes, simply crossing the road?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: When You Hear the F-Word, Try Picking Up More Than One Meaning
description: Some words have multiple parts. Some dirty words say multiple things.
content: People occasionally complain to me that so many today seem to lean on profanity rather than utilizing the other lexical resources at their disposal. “Why do they have to keep using that word over and over? What is that?” I was asked by someone of a certain age, for example, when I spoke at a gathering of academics last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Angry Drivers, Lots of Guns: An Explosion in Road Rage Shootings
description: Dozens have been reported in Texas alone amid a pandemic surge in gun purchases and a country increasingly on edge.
content: HOUSTON — The trouble started with an argument between two drivers merging in slow traffic after an Astros baseball game last summer. It ended with two gunshots, fired from a moving Buick and exploding through the glass of a fleeing Ford pickup truck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Solomon
title: Everything We Wanted to Know About David Shields (and Already Asked)
description: His new book is composed entirely of questions posed in interviews over his long career.
content: THE VERY LAST INTERVIEWBy David Shields
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Volodymyr Yermolenko
description: A conversation with the Ukrainian philosopher and editor.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Volodymyr Yermolenko. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: When the Yankees Play the Blue Jays, ‘Every Game Is Huge’
description: A tense series between division rivals showcases everything that is right about the ultracompetitive American League East.
content: When he stepped to the plate to lead off Monday’s game against the Yankees, Toronto Blue Jays center fielder George Springer was greeted with a shower of boos from the crowd at Yankee Stadium. He promptly singled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: For One Black Whiskey Maker, Accolades and Now a Lawsuit
description: Eboni Major was blending award-winning bourbon at Bulleit but she alleges that just as she was becoming a public face of the brand, she faced discrimination at the distillery.
content: In March 2020, just before the pandemic shut everything down, the spirits company Diageo unveiled its latest product, a bourbon called Blenders’ Select.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Actors in ‘Waitress’ Tour Seek to Join Labor Union
description: Employees of a nonunion production are seeking improved compensation and safety protocols, saying a union version of the same musical pays better.
content: A group of actors and stage managers employed by a nonunion touring production of the musical “Waitress” is seeking union representation, emboldened by a growing focus on working conditions in the theater business and by the labor movement’s recent successes in other industries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: No reusable cup? In Australia, it’s at your own risk.
description: On a visit to Melbourne, a Times reporter got a lesson in cafe etiquette, and the challenges facing the sustainability movement.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — The sour tone of voice from the barista could have curdled milk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Judge Bars 2 YouTubers From U.S.C. Campus
description: A lawsuit filed by the University of Southern California says the two men, who are not students, caused “terror and disruption” with what seemed like classroom takeovers.
content: A judge has barred two men from the campus of the University of Southern California in downtown Los Angeles after the university accused them of filming disruptive prank videos in classrooms for their YouTube channels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson Fined for Breaking U.K. Lockdown Rules
description: The British prime minister had seemed to turn the “partygate” tide with his handling of Ukraine. Then came the announcement that he broke the law.
content: LONDON — In recent weeks Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain has revived his fortunes at home by becoming Europe’s most aggressive supporter of Ukraine’s fierce fight against Russian invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Atul Loke
title: An Angry Public Wants Sri Lanka’s President Gone
description: Gotabaya Rajapaksa is used to silencing and discrediting his political opponents. But that’s harder to do this time.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — As Sri Lankans waited hours in line for fuel, sweated through the springtime heat during daily power cuts, and watched the value of their incomes erode, the president, Gotabaya Rajapaksa, blamed forces beyond his control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: How Young Latinos’ Online and TV Habits Offer Political Clues for 2022
description: A new report exploring young Latinos’ views on immigration sheds light on one of the most important voter groups in the midterm elections, and found a noteworthy gender divide.
content: Greetings from your co-host Leah Askarinam. Blake Hounshell is off this week. We have an item tonight from our colleague Jazmine Ulloa, who reports on a new analysis of young Latinos’ media habits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Mimi Reinhard, Who Typed Up Schindler’s List, Dies at 107
description: As a secretary in a forced-labor camp in World War II, she added her own name to the list of 1,100 Jews who would be spared from the gas chambers.
content: She wasn’t much of a typist, but she knew shorthand and spoke flawless German. And so Mimi Reinhard, an Austrian Jew who was being held in a Nazi labor camp near Krakow, Poland, during World War II, was given an office job. In that capacity, she would play a small but important role in one of the great heroic stories to emerge from the Holocaust, one in which the Nazis were outwitted and the lives of more than 1,100 Jews, including hers, were saved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Patricia Mazzei
title: Red States Push L.G.B.T.Q. Restrictions as Education Battles Intensify
description: With an eye toward parents’ anxiety, Republicans have put forward a wave of laws on classroom instruction, youth sports and health care. Some of the young people at the center feel isolated.
content: Last April, a high school senior in Utah named Gabriela Merida joined a student town hall hosted by her governor. She introduced herself, noted the pronouns she used and broached the subject of mental health challenges facing young L.G.B.T.Q. people. How, she asked, did the state plan to help constituencies like hers?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: A Ukrainian Philosopher on What Putin Never Understood About Ukraine
description: Volodymyr Yermolenko discusses how Russia’s invasion has reshaped Ukrainian identity.
content: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is only getting more brutal: We’ve seen the bodies of civilians strewn in the streets in Bucha, the city of Mariupol almost leveled and, just a few days ago, a Russian missile attack on a crowded train station in Kramatorsk killing at least 50 people. The United Nations has confirmed 1,793 civilian deaths in Ukraine, though the actual number is thought to be far higher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Rites of Spring
description: What do you enjoy about this season? What do you do to mark it?
content: Spring has sprung across the Northern Hemisphere. If, where you live, flowers are blooming, birds are making nests and the weather is getting warmer, what does that mean for you?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: El Quijote Tilts Back Toward Its Earlier Glamour
description: It’s not as cheap as it used to be, but after years of faded glory at the Hotel Chelsea, the mainstay Spanish restaurant has been revived.
content: There used to be dozens of Spanish restaurants around Chelsea and the Village, and while it was possible to argue over which had the best paella there was no serious debate about which was the grandest. It was El Quijote, in the Hotel Chelsea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: New DNA Analysis Supports an Unrecognized Tribe’s Ancient Roots in California
description: A collaboration between researchers and the Muwekma Ohlone Tribe offers new evidence that their ancestors have lived in the Bay Area for thousands of years.
content: In “The Handbook of the Indians of California,” published in 1925, the anthropologist Alfred Kroeber pronounced the Ohlone people “extinct so far as all practical purposes are concerned,” noting that only “a few scattered individuals survive.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: A German State Is Last in Almost Everything. But It’s No. 1 in Vaccines.
description: Bremen — Germany’s smallest state — managed its vaccination campaign better than any other place in Germany. It succeeded by activating community networks.
content: BREMEN, Germany — This northern port city, combined with neighboring Bremerhaven, makes up the smallest and by many measures the poorest state in Germany’s federal system. In state comparisons of education or addressing child poverty, it consistently ranks dead last.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: From the U.S. to China: A 3-Month Quarantine Horror Story
description: A lawyer flew home to China hoping to see his family for the first time since the pandemic began. Instead, he was trapped in three months of quarantine.
content: Before boarding his flight from Los Angeles to the Chinese city of Guangzhou, Xue Liangquan, a California-based lawyer, knew he was in for a bit of a headache.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Subway service resumes with delays and trains are bypassing 36th Street.
description: The attack at a subway station in the Sunset Park neighborhood of Brooklyn snarled subway lines all over the city, the authorities said, though many had picked up again by Tuesday night.
content: The attack at a subway station in the Sunset Park neighborhood of Brooklyn snarled subway lines all over the city, the authorities said, though many had picked up again by Tuesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Schaefer
title: A Surprising Global Dance Showcase, Deep in the Heart of Texas
description: Dance Salad, an annual festival in Houston, is the brainchild of Nancy Henderek, whose hands-on involvement even extends to editing some of the works.
content: Harold George, a young dancer from Sierra Leone, was studying in Belgium in 1992 when a friendly Texas expat named Nancy Henderek invited him to perform in a showcase at the international school her children attended. She called the concert Dance Salad because of its bite-size sampling of styles and artists, including some of the city’s best professional companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Should I Have Lied to Help My Kid Brother Get Vaccinated?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what we gain from making hard choices.
content: My brother is 16 and lives with my parents. I am in my 30s and live several hours away. We have good relationships with one another, although my parents are extremely anti-Covid vaccine and anti-mask. They cannot be reasoned with over the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir and Andy Newman
title: Videos Show an Ordinary New York Morning Erupting Into Chaos on the N Train
description: The attack on Tuesday brought to life a horror that the city had long avoided: a mass shooting on the subway.
content: On videos captured inside a smoke-choked subway car, commuters can be seen hunching into their collars, pulling sleeves and hoods across their faces, trying to breathe. Before the doors open, there are few panicked screams — just the familiar muffled shriek of a rush hour train on its tracks, punctuated by moans of pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: What’s Shame Got to Do With It?
description: How and why we confuse shame and stigma.
content: In the old comic strip “The Family Circus,” four precocious children blamed invisible goblins — “Not me,” “Nobody” and “Ida Know” — for their messes. In the real world, adults who should be too old for invisible friends are doing the same deflection with a goblin named “Shame!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy and Nancy Wartik
title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhonda Garelick
title: Am I Done Suffering for Fashion?
description: Two years of a pandemic have lowered our patience for uncomfortable clothing.
content: As the world takes its hesitant steps toward normalcy, and more people return to the workplace, we need to accept the fact that the era of sweatpants may be drawing to a close. And yet, do we really want to abandon the freedom and comfort we have found during this otherwise grim time? I know I don’t. And apparently, I am not alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: On TV, the Truth Hurts
description: Television is hooked on scripted dramas based on real life. But they rarely measure up either to actual life or to actual drama.
content: As seen on the news, real life right now is heartbreaking, terrifying, depressing and exhausting. But as entertainment? Real life is hot, hot, hot, baby!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Putin’s defiance
description: The Russian leader spoke at length about his vision for the war.
content: President Vladimir Putin of Russia said that peace talks with Ukraine had reached a “dead end.” He also said there was “no doubt” that Russia would achieve its goals in a campaign that has left cities in ruins, forced millions to flee their homes and raised disturbing accounts of atrocities committed by Russian soldiers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: U.S. Report Describes a Global Retreat on Human Rights and Democracy
description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken says repressive governments “are growing more brazen” and reaching across borders to target their critics.
content: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Tuesday that governments around the world, including in Russia and China, grew more repressive last year, as the State Department released its annual report on global human rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Black Artists Lead Turner Prize Shortlist
description: This year’s nominees include a sculptor, a photographer and an artist who created a 31-foot statue of a dollop of whipped cream, with a fly on it.
content: LONDON — Ingrid Pollard, a pioneering Black female photographer, and Veronica Ryan, a Black sculptor who found widespread recognition in her 60s, are among the nominees for this year’s Turner Prize, the prestigious British visual arts award.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Name, phone, address: The writing on a child’s back is now a symbol of Ukrainian parents’ terror.
description: A mother who wrote emergency contact information on her 2-year-old’s back has become a voice for countless Ukrainian parents forced to do the same.
content: The mother’s hands were shaking when she started writing on her 2-year-old’s body. They trembled so much that she couldn’t write correctly on her first try, even though the information was second nature: Her daughter’s name, Vira, along with her birth date and their family phone numbers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘In the Ocean, It’s Snowing Microplastics’
description: In this lesson, students will learn how tiny bits of plastic have infiltrated the deep sea’s main food source and could alter the ocean’s role in an ancient cooling process.
content: Featured Article: “In the Ocean, It’s Snowing Microplastics” by Sabrina Imbler
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Putin Calls Talks a ‘Dead End’ but Limits War Aim to Eastern Ukraine
description: It was the first time that President Vladimir Putin himself had defined a more limited military goal: taking control of the Donbas region in the east of Ukraine — not the whole country.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said on Tuesday that peace talks with Ukraine had reached a “dead end” and he falsely called the evidence of Russian atrocities in a Kyiv suburb “fake,” using his first extended remarks about the war in nearly a month to insist that Russia would persist in its invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denny Lee
title: Glamorous Mermaids at Save Venice Gala
description: Guests included Lauren Santo Domingo, Alex Rodriguez and Sienna Miller.
content: Few galas are as over-the-top as the Save Venice ball, which took place last Friday at Cipriani South Street at the southern tip of Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘We Never Asked; He Never Explained’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: My husband, Stanley, was sick for months before he died in April 2019. Taking care of him, I didn’t have time to prepare our 2018 tax returns. With an extension to October, I sorted through Stanley’s checkbooks and credit card statements. His charges and payments reflected the cruel arc of his illness: Stanley’s business-related expenses plummeted while his medical costs ballooned; his handwriting deteriorated. I relived his death through his taxes. Sometimes those two certainties — death and taxes — intersect in unexpected, heartbreaking ways. By working slowly, I was able to fulfill Stanley’s final obligations. On time. — Zelda R. Stern
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Mayor Eric Adams says New York City will not surrender to the ‘violent few.’
description: Mr. Adams, a former police captain who ran on a public-safety message, recommitted to his anti-gun agenda in a speech on Tuesday night.
content: Facing a growing public-safety crisis, Mayor Eric Adams said on Tuesday night that a mass shooting had turned a Brooklyn subway into a “war zone,” and that gun violence was a national problem New York City could not solve on its own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Photos From the Scene of the Brooklyn Subway Shooting
description: Times photographers are at the location where several people were shot during the morning rush at a train station in Brooklyn.
content: A “person of interest” was identified by the New York police on Tuesday evening after a mass shooting at the 36th Street subway station in Brooklyn. At least 23 people were injured, officials said, in a violent episode that stoked fears about public safety as New York City struggles to recover from the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Heavy Floods and Mudslides Leave at Least 45 Dead in South Africa
description: Torrential rain left a trail of destruction in the coastal city of Durban — the latest disaster in a season of storms that some scientists say has been intensified by climate change.
content: JOHANNESBURG — Days of heavy rain on the eastern coast of South Africa left at least 45 people dead when rivers burst their banks and mudslides swept through the city of Durban and the surrounding area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Mets Collapse Late in Loss to Phillies
description: A 4-0 Mets lead turned into a 5-4 defeat. Steve Kwan of the Guardians, meanwhile, continues to dominate.
content: PHILADELPHIA — J.T. Realmuto hit a two-run homer in the eighth inning and Rhys Hoskins and Didi Gregorius followed with run-scoring doubles that helped the Philadelphia Phillies rally past the Mets, 5-4, on Monday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Casa Carmen, Mexican That’s a Family Affair, Opens in TriBeCa
description: A Japanese restaurant to replace O Ya in the Park South Hotel, a Latin-inspired cafe in the Bronx, and more restaurant news.
content: Carmen Ramírez Degollado’s husband helped open El Bajío in Mexico City, in 1972, and, when he died a few years later, Ms. Ramírez Degollado, known as Titita, took over the restaurant. Since 2006, El Bajío has opened 18 more family-owned restaurants, known for the food of Veracruz, Oaxaca, Puebla and the Yucatán. Now she’s 83, and two of her grandsons, Santiago Ramírez Degollado and Sebastián Ramírez Degollado, who live in New York, are opening this homage to her. It’s the first restaurant outside Mexico for the family behind the El Bajío company, in a simple, subdued space, done with rustic elegance. Clay pots line one wall. The menu lists assorted tacos and will feature duck tostadas, plantain empanadas, enchiladas de mole Xico, fish Veracruz-style and shrimp in a charred chipotle sauce. Desserts include a warm corn cake with ice cream. The executive chef for the group, Josep Rivera, will spend a few weeks to help grease the wheels before returning to Mexico, and the wine list will feature several Mexican wines. (Opens Thursday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadia Owusu
title: Two Strangers Meet in a Cafe in Cairo. What Happens Next Is Complicated.
description: In “If an Egyptian Cannot Speak English,” Noor Naga explores the forces of identity, belonging and globalism, as they bear down on two new lovers.
content: IF AN EGYPTIAN CANNOT SPEAK ENGLISHBy Noor Naga
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Novak Djokovic Returns to Clay, but Plays Little Like Himself
description: At the Monte-Carlo Masters, only the second tournament that the top-ranked Djokovic has played in five months, an unseeded 22-year-old handed him an upset.
content: Novak Djokovic’s tennis season like no other resumed Tuesday on home clay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Mark Zuckerberg Ends Election Grants
description: A spokesman for the Facebook founder said the money sent to election offices in 2020 was a “one-time donation.” The grants prompted Republicans to push for bans on private donations for elections.
content: Mark Zuckerberg, who donated nearly half a billion dollars to election offices across the nation in 2020 and drew criticism from conservatives suspicious of his influence on the presidential election, won’t be making additional grants this year, a spokesman for the Facebook founder confirmed on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: The federal consumer bureau sued TransUnion and a former executive over deceptive sales tactics.
description: The company repeatedly flouted a ban on luring consumers seeking free credit reports into paid products, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said.
content: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau sued the credit-reporting firm TransUnion and a former senior executive — John Danaher, who led the company’s consumer sales unit — for violating a 2017 order to stop using deceptive tactics to lure customers into recurring subscription payments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Missouri Williams
title: Rabbits Are Boring Pets. I Love Them Anyway.
description: My friends and family don’t get it. All I can do is try to describe what it’s like to be with them, the moments I’m not sure I can do without.
content: Everyone who knew anything about animals warned me against getting a rabbit in my early 20s, but I ignored them, and ended up with three. I inherited my first from a housemate, and then found the other two online after moving to the Czech Republic: one came from a teenage girl with too many extracurricular activities, the other from an elderly man who lived at the top of a tower block on the outskirts of town. He’d kept her for three years in a cage designed for pet rats, feeding her bird food and slices of brown bread. When I took her to the local vet, I was told that my rabbit had uterine cancer and a whole set of other health problems that needed treating at once. I duly shelled out the cash and spent the next couple of months nursing her back to health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: apprehensive
description: This word has appeared in 61 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word apprehensive has appeared in 61 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 17 in “Curling Drifts to the East, Where Rock Stars Are Being Born” by Sui-Lee Wee and Makiko Inoue:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Donors Pledge $41 Million to Monitor Thawing Arctic Permafrost
description: The six-year effort by climate scientists and policy experts aims to fill gaps in knowledge about planet-warming emissions and help affected communities in Alaska.
content: Climate scientists, policy experts and environmental justice advocates on Monday announced a major project to better understand the contribution of thawing permafrost to global warming and to help Arctic communities cope with its effects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward and Alexandra E. Petri
title: As U.S. cases tick up, the new White House Covid czar says it’s not a moment to be ‘excessively concerned.’
description: The official, Dr. Ashish Jha, said hospitalizations remained very low and that officials were monitoring the trajectory of the virus closely.
content: The new White House Covid-19 response coordinator, Dr. Ashish K. Jha, said Monday that while there had been a recent uptick in new U.S. coronavirus cases, he was not overly concerned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Ask for an Extension
description: If possible, make your request in person. And if you think you need two more hours, say you need four.
content: “If you think you’re going to turn in higher quality work if you have an extra day or two, you should proactively ask for more time,” says Ashley Whillans, an assistant professor at Harvard Business School who studies time and time poverty, a phenomenon she defines as “the feeling of having too many things to do and not enough time in the day to do them.” Some 80 percent of working adults report experiencing this time crunch. Asking for an extension is one way to alleviate some of that pressure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: All Children 8 and Older Should Be Screened for Anxiety, U.S. Task Force Says
description: A panel of experts says the latest research supports early intervention for younger kids.
content: The worsening state of mental health among children has prompted an influential group of experts to recommend for the first time screening all children ages 8 to 18 for anxiety, one of the most common mental health disorders of childhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Most Active Hurricane Season Was Also Wetter Because of Climate Change
description: During the record-setting 2020 Atlantic storm season, the most extreme three-hour rainfall rates were 10 percent higher than they would have been without climate change, a new study found.
content: Climate change contributed significantly to the severity of the ferocious 2020 Atlantic hurricane season, increasing both rainfall rates and rainfall totals, according to a study published on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosemary Mosco
title: Why City Pigeons Are Worth Watching
description: The humble Columba livia is much more than a rat with wings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: In Conference Call Before Riot, a Plea to ‘Descend on the Capitol’
description: Days before Jan. 6, a onetime aide to Roger J. Stone Jr. told Trump backers to make lawmakers meeting to finalize the 2020 election results feel that “people are breathing down their necks.”
content: One week before an angry mob stormed the Capitol, a communications expert named Jason Sullivan, a onetime aide to Roger J. Stone Jr., joined a conference call with a group of President Donald J. Trump’s supporters and made an urgent plea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Russian plans for a new assault on Ukraine.
content: After meeting with Vladimir Putin yesterday, Karl Nehammer, the Austrian chancellor, said he feared that the Russian president intended to drastically intensify the brutality of the war. “The battle being threatened cannot be underestimated in its violence,” Nehammer said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: In the Shadow of the Border Wall, a Catholic Kitchen Provides Hope and a Hot Meal
description: La Tilma, a restaurant run by Sacred Heart Catholic Church in El Paso, nourishes the lives of many Mexican immigrants in poverty.
content: EL PASO — Twenty years ago, Amelia Lopez Patrykus stood outside Sacred Heart Catholic Church, waiting for a free meal and groceries. The line was just blocks from the Rio Grande, separating Mexico from her new home in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: More Companies Take a Stand on Abortion
description: Yelp is the latest to pay for employees to travel out of state for treatment, responding to a recent Texas law that bans abortions after six weeks.
content: Yelp, the online search and review platform, is expected to announce today that, beginning next month, it will cover expenses for its employees and their spouses who must travel out of state for abortion care, The Times’s Alisha Haridasani Gupta and DealBook’s Lauren Hirsch report. It is the latest company to respond to the Texas law that bans abortion after about six weeks of pregnancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Erin Griffith and Kate Conger
title: Welcome Back to the Office. Isn’t This Fun?
description: Tech companies really want their employees to be happy — or at least less annoyed — about returning. So they’re providing concerts, food trucks and other perks.
content: When Google employees returned to their mostly empty offices this month, they were told to relax. Office time should be “not only productive but also fun.” Explore the place a little. Don’t book back-to-back meetings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Hochul Picked a Running Mate. Now She Has to Pick Another One.
description: Lt. Gov. Brian Benjamin’s resignation in the face of a criminal indictment creates a major political test for Gov. Kathy Hochul.
content: One of the first decisions Gov. Kathy Hochul had to make when she suddenly ascended to New York’s highest office last summer was a personnel one: Who would fill her previous role as lieutenant governor, becoming her second-in-command and running mate in the 2022 election?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Nelsen, J. David Goodman and Edgar Sandoval
title: As Texas Snarls Traffic at Border, Mexican Truckers Form Blockade
description: New safety inspections are part of Gov. Greg Abbott’s effort to crack down on border smuggling. But industry groups say it is stifling trade.
content: PHARR, Texas — Trucks attempting to enter Texas loaded with goods from Mexico sat motionless for hours on Tuesday as lengthy vehicle inspections ordered by Gov. Greg Abbott in a clash with the Biden administration over immigration snarled traffic at major commercial crossings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Unraveling a High-Rise Horror Story
description: A tip about elevator breakdowns at a high-rise residential building in Lower Manhattan proved to be more than just griping.
content: Last month, when Karen Zraick, a Times reporter on the Metro desk, got a tip from a tenant of a Lower Manhattan residential building, she wasn’t sure it would result in an article. The tipster wrote that elevator service in the building had been spotty, at best, since the fall. But elevator outages are unfortunately fairly common in New York City, particularly in the city’s public housing complexes, Ms. Zraick thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Panic in Brooklyn Subway: Police Hunt Gunman Who Shot 10
description: At least 23 were injured, five critically, in an attack at the 36th Street stop in Sunset Park after a man released two smoke grenades and started shooting.
content: Hours after a gunman in an orange construction vest released two smoke grenades and fired at least 33 shots on an N train in Brooklyn, hundreds of police officers were searching Tuesday night for a 62-year-old man whom police officials have linked to the shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Karl-Anthony Towns and the ‘Swaggy’ Timberwolves Are Ready
description: Towns, the Timberwolves center, said he’s never doubted himself and now he has the right team behind him. “Whatever it takes to win, we will do as a team,” he said.
content: Karl-Anthony Towns has rarely experienced the kind of professional joy he has had this season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Jenny Vrentas
title: Congress Refers Commanders’ Alleged Financial Malfeasance to F.T.C.
description: In a 20-page letter sent to the F.T.C., a congressional committee passed along allegations from a former employee who said the team withheld ticket revenue from fans and the league.
content: A congressional committee looking into wrongdoing within the Washington Commanders N.F.L. franchise referred to the Federal Trade Commission allegations of potentially unlawful financial practices by top executives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Morales
title: Chick Corea, the Master Mixer of Jazz’s Past and Future
description: An eclectic array of musicians will gather in New York to celebrate the pianist’s legacy. Five collaborators and admirers discuss his experiments, artistry and generosity.
content: When the groundbreaking pianist Chick Corea died unexpectedly, at 79, last February, he left a legacy of experimentation, preserving and expanding the jazz tradition. Over more than a half-century, he deftly navigated the music’s continually shifting boundaries. Corea started his career playing with the Afro-Cuban percussionist Willie Bobo and spent time with the bossa nova stalwart Stan Getz. His presence in Miles Davis’s “Bitches Brew” ensemble, and later, his leading role in Return to Forever, gave him a seminal role in the origins of 1970s jazz fusion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: House G.O.P., Banding Together, Kills Bid to Honor Pioneering Black Judge
description: A right-wing congressman persuaded fellow Republicans to abruptly turn against a routine measure to name a federal courthouse in Florida for a Black State Supreme Court justice.
content: WASHINGTON — In a bitterly divided Congress, it was a rare measure that had been expected to sail through without a fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: Reader Questions: Theater District Edition
description: Tips for eating around Broadway, whether you have time for a sit-down meal or just a quick bite before the curtains go up.
content: It is a heavy day in New York City following news of the shooting at a subway station in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. I’m keeping the victims in my thoughts, and I hope you will, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Review: ‘The Little Prince,’ a Lumbering Circus
description: A stage version of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry’s classic of children’s literature lands on Broadway but remains stubbornly earthbound.
content: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry’s “The Little Prince,” a megaselling classic of children’s literature first published in 1943, begins with a crash landing. Now, an adaptation of the beloved tale has made a similarly unfortunate entrance on Broadway.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Ballets, Bars and Bomb Scares: Lviv Learns to Live With War
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 12, 2022.
content: “If people day by day are faced with sad news about death, about blood, about bombs, they need to feel other emotions.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold and Steven Erlanger
title: Ukraine War Pushes Germans to Change. They Are Wavering.
description: In just six weeks since Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced a strategic shift for his country, already doubts are emerging about how real and deep it is.
content: BERLIN — Chancellor Olaf Scholz surprised the world, and his own country, when he responded to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine with a 100-billion-euro plan to arm Germany, send weapons to Ukraine and end his nation’s deep dependence on Russian energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Joel Grey, on Making a Space for Art and Dreams
description: The prolific actor, writer and photographer just turned 90, in a 1970s-style West Village loft that speaks to his many passions.
content: Rain threatened on a recent Tuesday morning, and there was a chill in the air. But inside Joel Grey’s loft in Manhattan’s West Village, it was spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Nebula, a Big New Club, Wants Manhattan to Dance Again
description: Yang Gao, a newcomer to the nightlife business, took a gamble when he spent $12 million in the middle of a pandemic to carve out a 10,000-square-foot space in the heart of Midtown.
content: Two years ago, Yang Gao and Richie Romero were watching over a very noisy and very expensive construction project: Digging down, down, down, beneath the floor of an old building on West 41st Street, just off Times Square.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Ups and Downs of Remote Work in New York
description: People like working in their pajamas. But when employees don’t return to office, the city economy feels the pain.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at how the pandemic is rewriting the people-in-offices model that sustained Manhattan for generations. And, a playwright who decided not to change the name of her play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain and Tomás Munita
title: Where the Ice Is Still Abundant, These Penguins Are, Too
description: The western side of the Antarctic Peninsula has seen sharp declines in Adélie penguin populations in recent decades. Things look better on the eastern side. Take a tour.
content: Adélie penguins have had a rough time of it on the western side of the Antarctic Peninsula, where warming linked to climate change has occurred faster than almost anywhere else on the planet. That and other factors have led to sharp declines in Adélie populations in recent decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Globally, inflation is surging amid persistent pandemic disruptions and war in Ukraine.
description: This may be the beginning of “a new inflationary era,” according to the Bank for International Settlements.
content: Just as in the United States, policymakers in other countries have been caught off guard by persistently high inflation. Price increases were expected to ease as economies recovered from the pandemic, but surging energy and food prices have continued to lift inflation around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Lauren Hirsch
title: Yelp Will Pay for Employees to Travel for Abortion Access
description: The company has relatively few workers in Texas, which has the most restrictive abortion law.
content: Yelp announced on Tuesday that it would cover expenses for its employees and their spouses who must travel out of state for abortion care, becoming the latest company to respond to a Texas law that bans the procedure after about six weeks of pregnancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samuel Hammond
title: To Help Children, Democrats Are Going to Have to Reach Across the Aisle
description: A bipartisan child tax credit expansion may actually be within reach.
content: The expiration of the child tax credit expansion late last year sent an estimated 3.7 million children back into poverty and undermined the financial security of millions more. With the rising cost of living squeezing family budgets, the expiration of the credit could not have been more poorly timed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: What’s Happening With Abortion Legislation in States Across the Country
description: A cascade of restrictive abortion legislation is being proposed in Republican-led states.
content: A law signed by Gov. Kevin Stitt of Oklahoma on Tuesday makes it a felony, punishable by up to 10 years in prison, to perform an abortion in the state. It is the latest in a cascade of restrictive abortion legislation proposed in Republican-led states across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen and Peter Keepnews
title: Gilbert Gottfried, Comedian With a Distinctive Voice, Dies at 67
description: His credits ranged from the family-friendly “Aladdin” to the unfettered vulgarity of “The Aristocrats” and included a brief stint on “Saturday Night Live.”
content: Gilbert Gottfried, the comedian who gave voice to the parrot in the hit Disney animated feature “Aladdin” and the duck in commercials for Aflac insurance — and whose manic, loudmouthed and highly original stand-up routines mixed old-fashioned borscht-belt shtick with cringeworthy vulgarity — died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: Amid Soaring Demand for Warehouses, an Effort to Make Them Greener
description: Some owners are taking steps to make their buildings more energy efficient, including upgrading building materials and turning the rooftops into solar farms.
content: Warehouses and distribution centers, decidedly unsexy buildings, became hot in the coronavirus pandemic as online shopping accelerated the rise in e-commerce and set off a frenzy of buying and building the boxy, low-rise structures, pushing up rents and increasing returns for investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Pickert
title: A Nurse Finds Herself on the Other Side of the Equation — as a Patient
description: In her memoir, “Healing,” Theresa Brown recalls what she learned from her own treatment for breast cancer.
content: HEALINGWhen a Nurse Becomes a PatientBy Theresa Brown
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Driving Force
description: Dan Schoenholz’s puzzle is a job well done.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Some crossword constructors really excel at themeless puzzles, which typically run on Fridays and Saturdays. These puzzle makers focus on long entries that are fresh and exciting, and they emphasize cluing. For other constructors, the driving force behind their grids is an uncanny ability to generate clever wordplay-based themes and theme sets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Megan Specia and Rick Gladstone
title: Western powers look into an unverified claim of possible use of a chemical agent in Mariupol.
description: Ukrainian commanders said “a poisonous substance” caused respiratory difficulties and neurological symptoms in a handful of soldiers and civilians.
content: The United States, Britain and other Western allies, along with Ukraine’s government, are examining claims that Russia deployed a chemical agent that sickened a handful of people in Moscow’s unrelenting bid to gain complete control over the ruined Ukrainian city of Mariupol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leone Ross
title: She’s a 12-Year-Old Girl and Also a Spirit That Can See Into Her Family’s Past
description: In her debut novel, “Things They Lost,” Okwiri Oduor uses magical realism to explore toxic mother-daughter relationships.
content: THINGS THEY LOSTBy Okwiri Oduor
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: As Families Grieve, Grandparents Step Up
description: As many as 200,000 U.S. children have lost a parent to Covid. Their grandparents are taking them in and helping them heal, all while coping with their own grief.
content: As many as 200,000 U.S. children have lost a parent to Covid. Their grandparents are taking them in and helping them heal, all while coping with their own grief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barbara Marcolini, Sanjar Sohail and Alexander Stockton
title: The Taliban Promised Them Amnesty. Then They Executed Them.
description: An Opinion Video investigation reveals the Taliban have been on a crusade of revenge killings against former U.S. allies.
content: An Opinion Video investigation reveals the Taliban have been on a crusade of revenge killings against former U.S. allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Collins, Lazaro Gamio, Evan Grothjan, Marco Hernandez, Taylor Johnston, Eleanor Lutz, Yuliya Parshina-Kottas and Amy Schoenfeld Walker
title: How the Brooklyn Subway Shooting Unfolded
description: Passengers rushed out of a smoke-filled N train in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, after a man opened fire during rush hour on Tuesday morning.
content: Passengers rushed out of a smoke-filled N train in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, after a man opened fire during rush hour on Tuesday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis and Katherine Schulten
title: Weekly News Quiz for Students: Ukraine Food Crisis, Supreme Court Confirmation, Asteroid Shards
description: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
content: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Spain Reigns Again
description: One of New York’s oldest Spanish restaurants has been given a facelift and a completely new menu.
content: One of New York’s oldest Spanish restaurants has been given a facelift and a completely new menu.
source.name: The New York Times

title: At Home With Joel Grey, in the West Village
description: The prolific actor, writer and photographer just turned 90, in a 1970s-style loft that speaks to his many passions.
content: The prolific actor, writer and photographer just turned 90, in a 1970s-style loft that speaks to his many passions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Deadly Flooding Strikes South Africa
description: Days of torrential rain unleashed floods and mudslides around the coastal city of Durban, leaving homes destroyed, infrastructure damaged and dozens dead.
content: Days of torrential rain unleashed floods and mudslides around the coastal city of Durban, leaving homes destroyed, infrastructure damaged and dozens dead.
source.name: The New York Times

description: An Opinion Video investigation reveals the Taliban have been carrying out revenge killings of former U.S. allies.
content: An Opinion Video investigation reveals the Taliban have been carrying out revenge killings of former U.S. allies.

author: By The New York Times
title: Video Shows Commuters on Train After Brooklyn Subway Attack
description: The video shows a smoke-filled subway car with passengers huddling on the floor. A wounded man can be heard yelling that he is in pain.
content: The video shows a smoke-filled subway car with passengers huddling on the floor. A wounded man can be heard yelling that he is in pain.

title: Russian Runners, Banned in Boston
description: Readers discuss Bret Stephens’s objections to the ban and whether Russian citizens should suffer because of their leader’s actions. Also: Merrick Garland and Jan. 6.
content: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: April 12, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, April 12, 2022.
content: An article on Sunday about efforts to save Florida’s starving manatees misstated where some of them went for the winter. It was northwest of the Indian River Lagoon, not northeast of it.
source.name: The New York Times
